justification: "We used the Moral Expansiveness Scale (MES; Crimston et al., 2016) to examine ascriptions of moral concern/worth to the present generation and the subsequent 50 generations hence."

measured_by: Single-item question: "How many future generations should we have in mind when we engage in collective decision making?"
justification: The authors state, "We captured this with a single item: 'How many future generations should we have in mind when we engage in collective decision making?'"
construct: Number of future generations considered in collective decisions

measured_by: Single-item question: "How many future generations should elected officials have in mind when they are making decisions about legislation?"
justification: The methods note that a "similarly-worded, single-item measure was thus employed: 'How many future generations should elected officials (i.e., the government) have in mind when they are making decisions about legislation?'"
construct: Number of future generations considered in governmental decisions

measured_by: Estimated indifference point for others using adapted Moral Expansiveness Scale
justification: Study 1b describes that "respondents were asked to estimate: (1) the generation at which other Americans feel no moral concern on average towards future people (in other words, the average indifference point, as conceptualized in Study 1a)."
construct: Perceived intergenerational moral concern among fellow Americans
